title: Tuesday, 14th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

Now, it seems 34,000 British millionaires have gone missing.

PM11:03am

I was trying to find a pic to illustrate that, but failed.

11:03 am
PM11:04am

So there's no pic for today

PM11:04am

But you can have the intro to the CS Wealth Report instead

PM11:04am

Incoming

11:04 am
PM11:04am

...

PM11:05am

The eighth edition of the Credit Suisse Research
Institute’s Global Wealth Report not only provides a
comprehensive annual update of global household
wealth development by segment and region, it also
takes a close look at the evolution and prospects
of the highly appraised Millennial generation,
whose members came of age after the turn of the
20th century.

PM11:05am

In general terms, throughout the twelve months
WRPLGZHREVHUYHGDVLJQLɇFDQWLQFUHDVHLQ
wealth across the globe, driven not only by equity
PDUNHWV EXW DOVR E\ VLJQLɇFDQW LQFUHDVHV LQ QRQ
ɇQDQFLDO ZHDOWK ,QWRWDO JOREDO ZHDOWK KDV JURZQ
by USD 16.7 trillion to USD 280 trillion, which
corresponds to a rise of 6.4%. We further saw an
increase of 2.3 million US-dollar-millionaires, almost
half of whom reside in the United States. Partially
due to a 3% rise in the value of euro against the US
dollar, we also note 620,000 new dollar-millionaires
in the main Eurozone countries Germany, France,
Italy and Spain. Another 200,000 joined in Australia
and about the same number appeared in China and
India together. We have seen a decline in millionaire
numbers in very few countries, mostly associated
with depreciating currencies: the United Kingdom
lost 34,000 and Japan lost over 300,000.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

In general terms, throughout the twelve months

wealth across the globe, driven not only by equity

by USD 16.7 trillion to USD 280 trillion, which
corresponds to a rise of 6.4%. We further saw an
increase of 2.3 million US-dollar-millionaires, almost
half of whom reside in the United States. Partially
due to a 3% rise in the value of euro against the US
dollar, we also note 620,000 new dollar-millionaires
in the main Eurozone countries Germany, France,
Italy and Spain. Another 200,000 joined in Australia
and about the same number appeared in China and
India together. We have seen a decline in millionaire

PM11:05am

There are those missing millionaires

PM11:06am

Our home market Switzerland has seen wealth
per adult increase by 130% to USD 537,600 since
the turn of the century and continues to lead the
global rankings. Again, we note that a large part of
the rise is associated with the appreciation of the
Swiss franc against the US dollar between 2001
and 2013. Nonetheless, measured in Swiss francs,
domestic household wealth rose by 35% since
2000, which corresponds to an average annual rate
of 1.8%. Switzerland today accounts for 1.7% of the
top 1% of global wealth holders and over two-thirds
of Swiss adults have assets above USD 100,000.
8.8% of Swiss are US-dollar millionaires and an
estimated 2,780 individuals are in the ultra-high
net worth bracket, with wealth over USD 50 million.
Financial assets continue to make up 54% of gross
wealth in Switzerland, which is less than in Japan or
the United States and debts average USD 140,500
per adult, which is one of the highest absolute levels
in the world, although we continue to believe that the

11:06 am
PM11:06am

development, rather than excessive borrowing.
On the worrying end, among the ten countries for
which long series of wealth distribution are available,
6ZLW]HUODQG LV DORQH LQ KDYLQJ VHHQ QR VLJQLɇFDQW
reduction in wealth inequality over the past century.
Looking at the bottom of the wealth distribution,
3.5 billion people – corresponding to 70% of all
adults in the world – own less than USD 10,000.
Those with low wealth tend to be disproportionately
found among the younger age groups, who have
had little chance to accumulate assets, but we
ɇQG WKDW 0LOOHQQLDOV IDFH SDUWLFXODUO\ FKDOOHQJLQJ
circumstances compared to other generations.
Although relatively less severe in some emerging
markets, capital losses during 2008–2009, high
unemployment, tighter mortgage rules, growing
house prices, increased income inequality, less
access to pensions and lower income mobility have
dealt serious blows to young workers and savers and
hold back wealth accumulation by the Millennials in
many countries. With the baby boomers occupying
most of the top jobs and much of the housing,
Millennials are doing less well than their parents
at the same age, especially in relation to income,

home ownership and other dimensions of well-
being assessed in this report. While Millennials

are more educated than preceding generations
(we see an increase of more than 20% in tertiary
education across OECD countries), we expect

only a minority of high achievers and those in high-
GHPDQG VHFWRUV VXFK DVWHFKQRORJ\ RU ɇQDQFHWR

effectively overcome the “millennial disadvantage.”
We also note that entrepreneurship, as measured
by the fraction of self-employed workers, has been
declining across OECD countries since the turn of
the century, including Millennials who are generally
touted as a generation of entrepreneurs.

PM11:07am

Sorry for the formatting snafus

PM11:07am

Can't get rid of that.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

I will share in the usual place

undefined
PM11:08am

Plenty of statements out today

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Big and small and medium

PM11:08am

Companies that is

BE11:08am

Sure, yep, decent amount of corporate.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Of which ITV's probably the most interesting.

PM11:08am

Outside the markets -- in Britain -- it's a big Brexit day, but I'm really sick of that

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 149.20, down 4.8 (-3.12%), High: 160.40, Low: 142.80, Volume: 32.14m
11:08 am
PM11:09am

Yeah, ITV

PM11:09am

Been all over the place this morning

PM11:09am

Spike at the outside. Not sure what that was about

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Advertising's pretty bad, but there's a fair bit of debate about how much should've been anticipated.

BE11:10am

ITV Family NAR down 7% for the nine months.

BE11:10am

Guidance goes for 1% in Q4, so that's a 5% decline in the full year.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Soft guidance about consumer goods companies coming back and spending a wee bit more, which was initially read as positive .....

BE11:12am

..... though for the longer run it looks like forecasts are coming back a wee bit.

BE11:12am

Let me cut to Investec.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

UK macros/ad prospects are tough near term, but the shares arguably discount this, with some M&A backstop plus a new well-regarded CEO from January 2018. Our probability-weighted PT (220p) is based on an ongoing SOTP (75% weighting) and bid potential (at a 30% premium). Valuation – cheap on a CY18E P/E of 10x and full liability EV/EBITDA of 9x. FCF/dividend yield 6%/5%

BE11:13am

Outlook – on track for FY expectations. ITV guidance for 4Q ITV Family NAR is +1% vs our current f/c -2% (consensus similar to us) so better and FY17E -5% vs f/c -5.5% (3Q -4%/1H -8%). On FY18E NAR, we f/c -1% (consensus flat), but would like to hear more from ITV on this following today’s news flow and consensus expectations. Studios – good sales growth, but flat profit given drama investment and tough (Talpa/margin) comps: as previous comments.

 Forecasts U/R – if we flow through slightly better NAR to FY, this implies FY17E EPS c. +1.5% to 15.4p. We are cautious on changing FY18E given continuing UK Brexit issues and ITV comment on £15m extra costs next year. Current FY17/18E adj.
FD EPS 15p/15p vs FactSet consensus at 16p/16p.

BE11:13am

And Jefferies ..........

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Derating unjustified: While recognizing the challenges posed by the current cyclical slowdown in ad spending, we remain positive on ITV as we expect 1) an inflection in NAR performance as outlined above, 2) the high growth and high margin OPI segment to capture larger audiences through ITV Hub, commanding greater pricing and sponsorship possibilities, 3) solid performance from ITV Studios, further diversifying the business, and 4) a dividend underpinned by a strong balance sheet.

Valuation. ITV is the cheapest of the broadcasters, trading on 9.7x 2018E EPS vs. peers on 13.1x, or a 30% discount to the FTSE100 (vs. 5-year historic of +1%). Dividend yield of 7.8% (including special) and FCF yield of 10% support.

BE11:14am

And ... oh, I dunno ... Shore?

BE11:14am

Current trading / outlook comments within this morning’s statement indicate “improving trends” in all key revenue lines in Q3 and confirm that the company is on track to meet management expectations for the full year. ITV Family NAR is expected to decline by 5% YoY during FY2017F (with signs of a return to TV advertising by some FMCG’s and Grocers despite the impact of political and economic uncertainty on broader corporate confidence. Online Pay and Interactive activities are expected to generate “strong revenue growth” and there is also confirmation that the Studios business is expected to generate good organic revenue growth and has a “healthy pipeline “ of new and returning programmes” in place for 2018. As expected the business remains on track to deliver £25m of cost savings across the full year.

We are reassured by the steady guidance summarised above which reinforces our confidence in our full year forecasts following precautionary downgrades in early October to reflect a greater degree of caution on advertising (we assume a YoY NAR decline of 5.5% including a 2.0% YoY reduction during Q4 - despite weak comps). We also note with interest the comments highlighted above.

More broadly, we continue to believe that this cautious outlook is already more than reflected in the valuation of ITV’s stock (FY2017F and FY2018F P/E and DY ratios of 10.0x 9.7x and 5.3% 6.1% respectively) and that a period of share price weakness (-9% and -18% over one and six months respectively) has been heavily influenced by concern over short-term advertising spend rather than a more fundamental assessment of the group’s medium-term attractions. The latter include: (a) an unrivalled ability to deliver a mass market commercial audience (a characteristic still highly prized by advertisers) via a trusted well-understood medium; (b) the scale and commercial value of its content portfolio; (c) the prospect of an attractive income progression (SCF three year agg. underlying DPS growth 18%) and strong cash generation (providing firepower for acquisitions, dividend growth further “special” payments (29.3p to date), and de-leveraging an already under-geared balance sheet), and; (d) its value as a strategic asset within a consolidating industry. We retain our Buy recommendation.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Problem here is that nearly everyone's a buyer of ITV, except for the buyside. And while the analysts are happy to see guidance stand still, that's ignoring an underlying caution in the statement that seems to be the bigger worry.

PM11:16am

hmm

BE11:17am

Remember all those presentations from ITV trying to emphasise that it's not just a proxy of monthly ad sales? Well .......... hasn't quite worked.

11:17 am
PM11:18am

Indeed

undefined
BE11:18am

On the other side of the board we have Vodafone ....

11:18 am
Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 227.85, up 11.85 (+5.49%), High: 228.00, Low: 223.95, Volume: 49.05m
BE11:19am

@Mark Shapland asks, isn't Vod supposed to be struggling? Well, yes and no.

PM11:19am

Vodafone mentioned on the right.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

It's an H1 beat and raise.

BE11:20am

Though as always with Vodafone, it's a complicated picture.

BE11:20am

Note the big slowdown in service revenue -- as in, the core -- which was +1.3% vs +2.2% in Q1.

11:20 am
PM11:21am

Yeah, I know it's always complicated with Voda -- but a 5% rise on a £60bn company that is researched to the nth degree...

BE11:21am

Indeed. The surprise here is the UK.

BE11:21am

+46% yoy organic increase in 1H EBITDA

11:21 am
BE11:21am

But that's against a 25% fall in the second half of last year.

BE11:22am

The UK market seems spectacularly volatile, and that's in part because there's a lot of noise in the figures.

BE11:22am

Here's SocGen.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Excluding the impact of handset financing, regulatory settlements and reallocation of central costs, we estimate UK EBITDA would have reduced by 1.9% yoy. In contrast to the significant improvement in the UK growth trend, 1H17/18 EBITDA growth in most of the other countries softened (when compared to the yoy growth recorded in 2H16/17), with the exception of Germany. Capex in 1H17/18 came in at €3,263m (i.e. €200m lower than consensus) and FCF at €1,300m (i.e. €200m ahead of consensus). Lower capex (vs consensus) has therefore contributed to the beat in FCF.

BE11:24am

.... all of which leads us down the path of what the hell to classify as a one off.

BE11:24am

Because Vodafone's definitions seem a bit tricksy.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

As per SocGen, the new guidance includes €300m of non-recurring effects from .....

BE11:25am

1) handset financing +€0.4bn (previously +€0.3bn), EU roaming €-0.2bn (previously -€0.3bn), and UK the increase in FY EBITDA guidance would have been c.€300m (representing a 2.1% upgrade).

BE11:25am

The upgrade based on mid-point of the range was 4-ish per cent.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Furthermore, it is worth highlighting that management guidance: a) excludes the recently announced increase in German capex for local fibre rollout (which for this year would be around c.€50-100m based on our estimates), and b) is based on unchanged forex estimates. We note that c.25% of Vodafone’s EBITDA is made in emerging markets (mainly South Africa, Turkey and Egypt), where on average inflation is c.10%, contributing to the recent weakness in their respective exchange rates vs the euro. As a result,
Vodafone’s guidance for organic growth benefits from local inflation but is not impacted by the associated forex losses. Based on current exchange rates (rather than unchanged forex), we estimate that FY17/18 EBITDA will be c.€300-350m lower than currently guided.

BE11:27am

... So, yeah, I have a degree of sympathy for the argument that Vodafone shouldn't be beating forecasts to this degree given it's covered by 30 or so analysts.

BE11:27am

But also, jees, it's a hell of a lot more complicated than just adding up the monthly subscribers and sticking the numbers into Excel.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Let me find a buyer for the sake of balance.

PM11:28am

Looking at the longer term chart for Vodafone -- it's basically gone nowhere since the Mannesmann deal

PM11:28am

When was that? 2002?

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Yeah, it's been dead money forever. It has the old problem of one bit going wrong for every three bits that are working.

PM11:29am

hehehehe

PM11:30am

(Janne -- good point)

11:30 am
BE11:30am

There's always another price war. Think it's currently Italy, India, France and the UK (the latter of which it can't really exit for historical reasons as much as anything).

BE11:31am

Oh, did you notice India figures? Service revenue down 17.8% and EBITDA fell 39%

PM11:31am

Indian mobile sector needs a proper look

11:31 am
PM11:31am

How Ambani (spell) has built his business so quickly is rather eye catching

BE11:32am

Similar to Illiad in France. MVNO means surprisingly low barriers to entry, I guess.

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:33 am
BE11:34am

JP Morgan .....

BE11:34am

Upgrades are diluted by a 1% FX revenue/EBITDA drag. Nevertheless Mar-18E revenues are unch, EBITDA +3%, EPS +10% and EFCF +5%. Mid-term upgrades are more modest due to upfront German "gigabit" spend, but scale up over time as this investment pays off. Mar-19 TP now 300p (prev 275p). EV/EBITDA 6.2x, divi yield 6.9%, EFCF 8.2%.

undefined
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Altice mentioned on the right .......... Interesting this.

BE11:35am

CDS has gone vertical.

PM11:35am

Really?

11:35 am
BE11:35am

PM11:35am

What was the trigger?

BE11:36am

Well ............. that's a fair question. The basics here are that Altice is limping along on €50bn debt, 5.2x leverage.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

We used to write about CDS a lot -- and it always fascinated me that the price would gap on a flaky PE bid story, but took ages to correct when said story provided to be wide of the mark.

PM11:37am

ie -- stupidly illiquid market, though everyone involved denied that.

BE11:38am

Hm. I'm not fully over this one, but mostly it's a case of core France deteriorating .....

11:38 am
BE11:38am

... which was brought home by the Q3 numbers, a few days ago.

BE11:39am

Morgan Stanley say this, this morning.

BE11:39am

A rising interest rate environment, coupled with tougher conditions in the High Yield TMT debt market. iii. Much of the Q3 EBITDA miss was driven by 'Other, Corporate and Eliminations'. Results in this division have been volatile, and include Altice Technical Services (ATS). iv. Altice's Q3 results saw Net Debt rise at SFR and Altice NV (while indebtedness fell at Altice USA). v. Altice NV CEO Michel Combes left the Group (9 Nov).

11:39 am
BE11:40am

And just look at the ratchet effect on the forecasts...

BE11:40am

Our updated model sees us cut our 2017-20e EFCF forecasts by -23% (on avg, due to the high leverage) and by -30% in outer years. The magnitude of our downgrades are lower than the recent -35% share price decline.

PM11:40am

blimey

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Our price target for Altice NV falls, from €20.5 to €13.5 per share – due to declines in our EFCF estimates, and also our revised price target of US$25 per share for Altice USA (was US$32 per share). This change is triggered by a mere ca -10% cut to our Target Enterprise Value (incl Net Debt) – again highlighting the magnified impact of leverage. Our new price target implies ca 30% upside. However, with leverage of greater than 5x and challenging EBITDA trends in France set to continue, we maintain our Equal-weight rating.

BE11:41am

It's the Punch Taverns of mobile phones.

BE11:42am

And I'm wondering aloud, apropos of nothing, if investors in the likes of Liberty Global might have a wee look at Altice and thing .... "hang on, if that can happen there then ...."

11:42 am
undefined
BE11:42am

Then there's Tesco, of course.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 186.90, up 9.9 (+5.59%), High: 187.50, Low: 179.85, Volume: 38.04m
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Booker cleared.

PM11:43am

Has Tesco ever had a competition ruling go against it on the M&A front?

BE11:44am

Not that I can remember.

11:43 am
PM11:44am

I'm not sure it has

BE11:44am

And this one's unconditional, which wasn't the assumption.

BE11:45am

Tesco and Booker do not compete directly in most activities. Where there is a local area with a Tesco store and Booker-supplier store, the level of competition in the grocery wholesale and retail markets would be sufficient to prevent the proposed merged company from raising prices or reducing service levels.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

The wholesale market will remain competitive in the longer term (with Booker currently at less than 20% market share).

BE11:46am

Which is interesting in part on the idea, mentioned here in the past, of Tesco letting Booker leases lapse and moving its stores into fallow Tesco Extra floorspace.

BE11:47am

Difficult to see how that gambit doesn't lessen competition. But I've not been through the CMA report so can't say whether they weighed up that eventuality.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Anyway, we get final report by end December so we're on track for competition by early 2018, assuming shareholders don't throw sand into the wheels.

PM11:48am

ok

BE11:49am

There remains a possibility for a bump, and there's lots of stuff in the archive about Booker shareholders wanting more cash.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

While on the subject, though, should mention food inflation heading higher again.

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 230.50, up 3.2 (+1.41%), High: 231.30, Low: 227.50, Volume: 3.39m
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 210.50, up 0.3 (+0.14%), High: 211.77, Low: 205.00, Volume: 2.23m
11:50 am
BE11:50am

(@Lefevre: what if it's intended for housewives who drop a lot of mobile phones down the toilet?)

BE11:51am

As per Kantar ....

BE11:51am

On a four-week basis, industry growth was +1.6%, compared with +3.0% in the four weeks to 8 October. Industry growth on a 12 week rolling basis was 2.6%, from 2.9% last period.

· Food inflation for the last 12 weeks increased slightly to 3.4% compared with 3.2% last period.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

The discounters’ combined sales growth in the four weeks to 5 November was 15.0%, higher than the 12.1% in the previous month. The discounters gained 104bps of market share in the four week period compared with 75bps last period.

· Tesco’s market share gain of 20bps came in ahead of last period’s -24bps loss and is also against tough comps last year. On a grocery basis Tesco gained 9bps of market share in the four week period, this is the first time Tesco has gained since June and is only the second market share gain this year.

BE11:51am

That's Barclays.

BE11:52am

"Prices are rising fastest in categories such as butter, fish and cola and prices are falling in only a few markets, including crisps and fresh poultry," they say.

11:52 am
undefined
PM11:53am

There is a bit of DPL if there's appetite.

PM11:54am

Knight Frank have a plan to build a extra layer of London

11:54 am
PM11:54am

40,000 new homes

BE11:54am

(@Mouselet: isn't it at least in part CAP related?)

PM11:55am

They've got themselves some sort of Sim City type software package

11:55 am
PM11:55am

To identify where you could build on roof tops

PM11:55am

It's an idea I guess

BE11:55am

This sounds great. Go on.

11:55 am
PM11:55am

New research conducted by global property consultancy Knight Frank, has found that as many as 41,000 new dwellings could be built in central London using rooftop development space, without altering the iconic skyline.

The study, which uses the latest geospatial mapping software, highlighted that more than 28 million sq ft of potential additional residential floor area could be developed, with this airspace having a potential value of £51 billion.

Stimulated in part by the 2017 Housing White Paper, the research project aimed to identify the extent of the Government’s pledge to seek out opportunities for higher-density housing in urban locations particularly “where buildings can be extended upwards by using the ‘airspace’ above them”. In response, Knight Frank has developed ‘SKYWARD’ – a method to systematically analyse the potential of each building.

PM11:56am

SKYWARD analyses 3D spatial data from the Ordnance Survey, cross referencing Land Registry data to assess ownerships and Historic England data to filter out listed buildings.

Representing the sheer scale of the opportunity, some 23,000 buildings could be suitable for rooftop development in Zones 1 and 2, and the volume of the unused plots across the same area is equivalent to eight Burj Khalifa towers (830m high), crucially without the corresponding impact on London’s skyline.

PM11:56am

There's a glossy pdf with all of this, but I can't make out much from the photos

11:56 am
PM11:56am

let me try and get one

PM11:57am

PM11:57am

Hmm, that's not very illuminating

11:58 am
PM11:58am

Anyway, talk to Knight Frank if you want to get involved with that.

BE11:58am

I'm all for building upwards. The UK, and London in particular, has a broken relationship with high rises.

BE11:59am

For reasons that have been written about several hundred times by the Guardian (except not by Simon Jenkins, who's 100% wrong on the theme).

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Anyway, since we're here, want some retirement homes?

BE12:00pm

McCarthy numbers are in line.

BE12:01pm

Quick line from Numis.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

McCarthy's update is broadly in-line with estimates although have reduced 2018/19
estimates by 4% to reflect a heavy H2 weighting to profits. We think that the shares
do look cheap relative to the sector, only trading at a 4% premium to Dec 2018 P/
NTAV. However, with the return on equity remaining low, a heavy H2 weighting to
profits and a high proportion of profits made from freehold sales, we think that risks
remain and we maintain our Hold rating and reduce our target price from 179p to
164p - equating to 1.16x Dec 2018 P/NTAV.

BE12:01pm

And, Peel Hunt? Why not Peel Hunt. Here's Peel Hunt.

BE12:02pm

FY17 was a tricky year for the group due to the impact of Brexit and the difficult second hand housing market. However, the group expects to deliver good volume and profit growth over the next few years, helping by its leading market position and demographic positioning. A cut in stamp duty or direct support for much needed retirement housing from the Government would provide a material boost. On unchanged forecasts, current valuations look too low. Buy.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

(@ROTR: we used to go to the Dickens Inn when at the white Times. Either it's improved in recent years or you're making a terrible mistake.)

McCarthy & Stone PLC (MCS:LSE): Last: 157.50, up 10.3 (+7.00%), High: 160.70, Low: 150.00, Volume: 543.34k
undefined
12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

Look at the time.

PM12:04pm

Thanks for all that Bryce

PM12:04pm

We'll be back tomorrow. Thanks for joining

12:04 pm
PM12:04pm

Bye

BE11:33am

Anyway, I guess the bottom line here is to ignore the quality of the numbers and feel a bit more secure with the dividend.
